review_text: I will start with how reserved I am normally about recommending places but I have ZERO reservations about recommending Nineteen06 in Patterson, LA. I have a love of everything old and love repurposing so I just took it all in -- the downstairs dining table craftsmanship, the upstairs coffee table made from beams, the upstairs whiskey barrel used as an end table, the downstairs cable spool coffee table, the upstairs display of the old post office boxes, the list goes on and on!!! All of the furnishings and decor are spot on! We spent time outside in the courtyard and thoroughly enjoyed our private oasis! Loved the white bicycle, the cable spool tables, all of the beautiful succulent planters on the back patio. I loved looking at the beautiful Bayou Teche that I grew up on decades ago. review_text:
There's so much good to say about this place, it's difficult to know where to begin or end. That said, so that I don't get carried away I'll try to stick with three aspects of this BnB that made my stay there an exemplary experience. However, I can assure the reader that there are many more reasons to stay here. Of all the BnBs I've stay at, this is the best so far!
For one, the space is beautifully designed and kept immaculate. From the flooring to the ceiling and everything in between including linens, the materials of this place are of the highest quality. Some of the materials are even reclaimed from nearby historical buildings. It seems there's a story behind a lot of the stuff you'll see in the BnB, and it's all been put together with taste.
Secondly, the location is ideal. There is a bayou right behind the building, and there is a park probably less than 100 feet away. In addition, there is a grocery store within a 10-minute walk through what looks to be the historic downtown district of Patterson.
Lastly, Jan and her husband have put a lot of effort into sharing their town with visitors. There is a lot of literature regarding local attractions at the entrance of the BnB, there are books about the area and the local landscape (e.g., the bayou Teche), and there are several pieces on the walls which depict the history and/or landscape of this part of the world.
I stayed here while in town for work, and I would love to come back. Highly recommended!

AC froze up the 1st night. We had to clean evaporator coil and thaw unit to get it working. Microwave, oven and refrigerator were dirty. Sugar ants were a constant problem in the kitchen. There was a leak in the ceiling above the living room and kitchen. Grill was dirty from previous guest. Kayaks were dirty with dry-rotted straps...we had to find rope to be able to secure the kayaks. Large rat living in the storage box on the upper deck where the life vests were stored. One working fishing pole but no tackle at all. They delivered 4 new small poles but still no tackle. Kitchen was functional but old and dirty cookware and minimal utensils. Old boat, needs a lot of work. Cannot recommend!!!!

review_text: Except for a delay and mix-up trying to check in, my stay at Steamboat Inn was strangely pleasant. The place is a step back in time, which fit perfectly with my reason for being in the area: genealogy and historical research. The kitchen, living areas and bathrooms are normally shared, but in this case, I had the entire house to myself! Even if other people had been there, I don't think it would have mattered. It was just pleasant. The Hosts, Charles and Wesley, were very friendly, and Charles was helpful in my research. He went out of his way to show me an old wooded cemetery lot out in the sugarcane fields. The kitchen has no stove or oven, but it does have a hotplate, which was adequate for my needs. There was a television in my bedroom, but not all of the rooms have TV's in them. The room was clean, spacious and charming as was the entire house. If you don't mind sharing a bathroom, this is a great place to stay, and the price is right.

I enjoyed my breakfast on the balcony watching cars pass below on Main Street, took sips of my Sazerac(s) seated in the front porch giving waves to locals, and grilled cajun sausages out back where there is a wrap-around porch with several settings for people with bistro tables, chairs and built-in benches. There is a very conveniently located Centerville Market next door with good choices of meats, veggies, drinks, snacks. I run regularly and ran East along mostly quiet LA-182 (Main Street). Charles introduced me to delicious meals in Franklin, at the Forest Restaurant (had fried crawfish and crawfish etoufee) and Guadalajara Mexican Grill (had camarones a la diabla).
